Description: Egyptian terracotta figurine of a crude dog standing and looking. Dog has a curly tail, probably a Sothic dog represenatation. Mould-made in a two piece mould, with the moulding lines reworked with a flat tool. Hollow. Organic red-brown Nile silt with grey core and abundant gold mica, organics, quartz and white shell or bone inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A number of Roman terracotta figures in the Fitzwilliam Museum are in the same style (Horse E.150.1914, E.106.1914, rider E.108.1914 and sothic dog E.149.1914). Close Roman parallel (Dunand 1990, no. 863). Dunand, F. 1990. Catalogue des Terres cuites gréco-romaines d’Egypte. Musée du louvre. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.198) (Phase 3)
